Main Content

Introduction

This document sets out the overall folder structure of the ON drives, as well as general file handling which includes naming conventions and sharing settings. This document is an interim readme prior to the new Design System, which will incorporate these standards.

When saving files on Google Drive, files should always be able to be stored on any of the 3 main Shared Drives â€“ if youâ€™re unsure where to save a file, new folders can always be added. The use of My Drive should be very limited, and ideally avoided.

All our files sit in these 3 main drives:

ON Communications

Comms & marketing, PR and social media

ON Resources

ON brand assets, brand applications, client logos, case studies, document templates and design resources

ON Projects

All active and archived project files (including internal projects)

Communications and Resources drives

The Resources drive contains all the raw material (including assets and templates) from which outputs can be created. These outputs then in turn live either in the Communications or Project drives. Final outputs should never live in the Resources drive.

Project drive: Standardised folder structure

The following folder structure is used for projects. Folders which don't apply get deleted (and numbers will adapt):

00 Received Files

Files and emails received from clients and partners logged chronologically

01 Project Management

Project scope/brief, timelines, gantt charts, and all other project management related files

02 Research

Collection of general desktop research, useful references etc

03 Strategy

Working files for any non-Figma based strategy work

04 Assets

Collection of all applicable file exports and assets used across teams

05 Design

Working files for any non-Figma based design work

06 Presentations and Deliverables

Working files for all presentations and deliverables for non-FIgma based work

Shared with client ðŸ‘¥

Presentation exports and other documents sent to clients logged chronologically

General file handling

The following standards ensure files and folders are easily found, managed and shared.

Folder naming

Make sure folders use self-explanatory names, describing its contents in a clear and concise manner.

Where possible, use a numbering system to create hierarchy in the folder. Always make sure to plan ahead â€“ keeping in mind new folders will be added at later dates.

Example 01 Working files 02 Exports

Sharing settings

Always make sure youâ€™re in control of who has access to what â€“ itâ€™s everyoneâ€™s responsibility to ensure the right people have the right access to the right files.

Sharing with clients

By default all folders and files on the ON drives are only accessible to ON members. When there is a need for files to be shared with clients, a separate folder can be set up within a project folder (see the project folder structure above). This folder can then safely be shared with the client by adding their email addresses in the permissions settings.
